Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD): Symptoms and causes

Generalized anxiety disorder is a common mental illness, affecting approximately 3% of the adult population. Among them, the proportion of children aged 13 - 18 years old with serious anxiety disorders accounts for about 6% [1]. If not detected and treated early, the patient will fall into depression, greatly affecting the quality of life. So what is generalized anxiety disorder (GAD)? What are the symptoms and causes of the disease?

What is generalized anxiety disorder (GAD)?
Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is a mental health condition where you are always in a state of fear and worry about activities happening in life such as work, health, and family. Generalized anxiety disorder has symptoms similar to panic disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and other types of anxiety. This condition affects both children and adults. Additionally, women are twice as likely to have generalized anxiety disorder as men.
Most people with generalized anxiety disorder have 1 or more other mental conditions, including:
Severe depression.; 1 specific phobia.; Social anxiety disorder.; Panic disorder.

11 typical symptoms of generalized anxiety disorder
Symptoms of generalized anxiety disorder are excessive worry, even hindering the patient in daily life activities. Symptoms of generalized anxiety disorder can progress over time and are often worse when they are under stress. [2]
Ongoing worry and tension may be accompanied by symptoms of clinical generalized anxiety disorder such as:
Excessive anxiety; Restlessness or tension; Easy fatigue, shortness of breath, rapid heartbeat; Difficulty concentrating.; Irritability, frustration; Muscle tension; Sleep disorders.; Panic disorder.; Fear of empty spaces or closed spaces; Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).; Social anxiety disorder.
In addition, generalized anxiety disorder (also known as generalized anxiety disorder) also manifests through specific symptoms including:
Persistent worry about small things..; Thinking too much about plans and solutions for all possible scenarios.; Feeling that situations in life can threaten you even when they do not cause harm; Unsure in giving direction; Indecisiveness. Fear of making wrong decisions; Unable to let go of unnecessary worries; Unable to relax, always feeling restless, stuck or stressed; Difficulty concentrating, always feeling blank.
Symptoms of generalized anxiety disorder may progress over time.

Causes of generalized anxiety disorder
It is still unclear what causes generalized anxiety disorder. However, the following factors can increase the risk of disease:
Genetic.; Childhood obsession: ever being abused.; Long-term painful health condition: chronic disease; Being in a stressful environment.; History of drug or alcohol abuse.

Subjects at risk of disease
Women are diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder twice as often as men. In addition, the following subjects are susceptible to generalized anxiety disorder [3]:
Personality: people with a shy, negative or avoidant temperament are more susceptible to generalized anxiety disorder than others; Genetics: generalized anxiety disorder can run in families; Family history: people with generalized anxiety disorder have experienced traumatic, negative events in childhood or recently. In addition, chronic medical illnesses or other mental health disorders can also increase the risk.
When the following signs appear, the patient should see a doctor or psychologist:
Feel like you're worrying too much and it's affecting your work, relationships, or other aspects of your life.; Feeling depressed, irritable or having other mental health concerns; Having suicidal thoughts or behavior: this case requires immediate treatment.
Anxiety is unlikely to go away on its own, and may even become serious over time. Try to seek help from a doctor or psychologist before your anxiety becomes severe. Early treatment can quickly improve this condition.

Complications of generalized anxiety disorder
Generalized anxiety disorder can cause the following effects:
Reduced quality of work because it makes it difficult for the patient to concentrate; Inappropriate time allocation; Unnecessary energy consumption; Increased risk of depression.
Besides, generalized anxiety disorder can worsen other physical health conditions, such as:
Digestive or intestinal problems: irritable bowel syndrome or stomach ulcers.; Headaches and migraines; Chronic diseases.; Sleep problems and insomnia.; Heart.
Generalized anxiety disorder often occurs with other mental health problems, which makes diagnosis and treatment more difficult. Some mental health disorders that often accompany generalized anxiety disorder include:
Obsess.; Panic disorder.; Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).; Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).; Depression.; Having suicidal thoughts; Stimulant abuse.

How is generalized anxiety disorder diagnosed?
Doctors or psychologists often use the criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, published by the American Psychological Association, to diagnose generalized anxiety disorder. Criteria include:
Excessive anxiety for at least 6 months.; Unable to control anxiety.; Anxiety leads to feelings of distress or delays in daily activities.; Anxiety due to thyroid problems or stimulant use.
The patient's anxiety is also associated with 3 or more of the following symptoms for at least 6 months: Symptoms include:
Jitter.; Fatigue easily.; Difficulty concentrating.; Muscle tension; Having sleep problems.; Irritability.
When you see yourself or a family member showing signs of suspected generalized anxiety disorder, you should see a doctor or psychologist for timely treatment.
Psychiatrists will prescribe a number of tests to ensure there are no pathogens affecting the condition. Tests include:
Thyroid test.; Blood sugar test.; Echocardiography.; Test for stimulants (drugs).

Treatment of generalized anxiety disorder
Generalized anxiety disorder is often treated with psychological therapy (psychotherapy), medication, or a combination of both.
Psychotherapy (or talk therapy) is a term that refers to treatment techniques that help patients identify and change unhealthy emotions, thoughts, and behaviors.
1. Antidepressants
Medications prescribed to treat generalized anxiety disorder include:
Antidepressants: selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) antidepressants. It may take several weeks for the patient to start working again. In addition, some other medications include escitalopram (Lexapro), duloxetine (Cymbalta), venlafaxine (Effexor XR) and paroxetine (Paxil, Pexeva).; Anti-anxiety medications: Benzodiazepines are anti-anxiety sedatives that can help control severe forms of GAD. The medicine is effective in reducing anxiety quickly. Additionally, Buspirone is another anti-anxiety medication that may help treat GAD. Buspirone takes 3 – 4 weeks to be fully effective.
2. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)
Doctors and psychologists often use cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) to treat generalized anxiety disorder. During CBT therapy, your doctor will examine your thoughts and feelings and help you recognize your excessive anxiety. Through cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), patients can eliminate negative thoughts and behaviors and learn to adopt healthier habits, lifestyles, and thoughts.

Preventing generalized anxiety disorder
In addition to treatment, generalized anxiety disorder can be prevented by doing the following:
Follow a healthy lifestyle: limit caffeine use, get enough sleep, this can reduce anxiety symptoms when combined with treatment.; Manage stress by practicing yoga, meditating, and arranging work and fun activities appropriately.; Do not use drugs and alcohol: can make symptoms of generalized anxiety disorder severe, even affecting the medications being used to treat it.; Share with relatives and friends when experiencing stress, anxiety, insomnia, etc. or see doctors and psychologists for therapy.; Eating ensures that you provide enough necessary nutrients.
Generalized anxiety disorder can be treated with psychotherapy, medication, or a combination of both

Questions related to generalized anxiety disorder
1. Is generalized anxiety disorder dangerous?
Are not! Although generalized anxiety disorder is not dangerous, it can cause many consequences such as:
The patient isolates himself, unable to share his feelings and thoughts with people around him.; Decreased concentration, poor quality of work and study; Increased risk of depression, easy thoughts of suicide.; It's easy to turn to stimulants for relief such as drugs, alcohol, etc.; Negative effects on physical health.
2. Can generalized anxiety disorder be cured?
Have! Generalized anxiety disorder can be treated with psychotherapy, medication or a combination of both. If the patient responds well, the condition will improve after a period of time. Treatment effectiveness often depends on the severity and cause of generalized anxiety disorder.
3. Is generalized anxiety disorder hereditary?
Have! Although it is impossible to know the exact causes of generalized anxiety disorder, researchers have shown that genetics may be a causative factor. If a family member has the disease, there is a high chance that you also have generalized anxiety disorder.
4. Is generalized anxiety disorder depression?
Are not! Depression and generalized anxiety disorder are different conditions but often occur together. Generalized anxiety disorder can occur as a symptom of depression.
5. Where to get tested for generalized anxiety disorder? Which hospital?
Generalized anxiety disorder is mostly treated on an outpatient basis. Whether the patient is treated with medication, psychotherapy or a combination of both methods at the same time. When you or your family members have suspected signs of generalized anxiety disorder, you should not ignore or ignore your body but go to a general hospital, where many specialties combine for a comprehensive examination. face.

The customer care staff performs the task of welcoming, instructing, introducing, and providing information and advice on medical examination and treatment and policies to patients and family members throughout the medical examination and treatment process at the hospital. institute.

If you suspect that you or a family member has signs of generalized anxiety disorder, you should seek help and advice from a doctor or psychologist for early treatment and to avoid negative consequences caused by the disease. .
